awd_titl_txt: Transforming Ethics Education: Connecting STEM Faculty, Research Administrators, and Ethics Education Resources through the Online Ethics Center
awd_abstract_narration:
STEM ethics education is an integral element of the effort to facilitate ethical science and protect against research misconduct. The Online Ethics Center is the nation's premier online platform for storing, curating, and discussing state-of-the-art information about teaching research ethics, Responsible Conduct of Research, and fostering ethical cultures within science and engineering. The goal of this project is to update and improve the Online Ethics Center (OEC). The investigators will do so by better engaging faculty and administrators who are new to teaching ethics, and by conducting a series of workshops with the user community that will enable them to gather multiple types of social science data and systematically assess how the OEC can better meet the needs of its constituents. Grant funds will also be used for regular site maintenance and to hire an expert external evaluator to formally assess OEC's activities and aid the investigators in improving site usability and updating the resource collection that they provide. Together, these efforts will help improve the quality of STEM ethics education and encourage and equip U.S. researchers to engage in ethical scientific practice.

The main goal of this project is to update and improve the Online Ethics Center (OEC). To do so, the investigators will engage in a systematic social scientific assessment of the OEC and its user community. This will enable them to understand how the site can be modified to better meet the needs of its constituents and to provide more and higher quality resources to its user community. They will do so first by gathering data at the STEM ethics education workshops that they will organize, and through interviewing and surveying members of their user communities. Second, the investigators would solicit, develop, and curate new and enhanced resources for advancing STEM ethics education. Third, the investigators will fund ongoing site maintenance while significantly improving its functionality. Finally, the investigators will hire a part-time consultant to act as an expert evaluator to formally assess: (1) site usability; (2) user demographics; (3) visitors' purposes for coming to the site and whether they were able to find what they were looking for; (4) the uses to which visitors put site resources; (5) which aspects of the OEC users find most and least helpful; and (6) how the resource collection might be improved.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Online Ethics Center (OEC) provides quality Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) ethics education resources and connects practitioners, researchers, and educators to promote learning and advance understanding of responsible research and ethical practice in STEM. 

Awarded in 2018 to the National Academy of Engineering, the project called “Transforming Ethics Education: Connecting STEM Faculty, Research Administrators and Ethics Resources through the Online Ethics Center sought to: “(1) help transform education in the responsible conduct of research (RCR), (2) advance the CCE STEM program mission of fostering an ethical culture in education and practice, and (3) become a key, self-sustaining part of a comprehensive approach to improve the ethical culture and integrity at US research and STEM education institutions.” 

These goals were formulated to serve two audiences: science and engineering (S&E) faculty new to teaching ethics, and university administrators responsible for implementing RCR requirements. With these goals in mind, the OEC leadership developed two objectives for the project: “(1) engage and equip S&E faculty with tools and resources that will enable them to infuse ethical values and training in their disciplinary courses, and (2) engage and support the work of university administrators and others responsible for educating students, postdocs, and faculty about research integrity and RCR and for facilitating a culture of ethical and responsible research and practice at their institutions.” 

In 2021, the decision was made to transition the OEC from the NAE to the University of Virginia (UVA). This included not only changing its institutional home, but also moving its technology infrastructure, the content management system. 

The OEC Advisory Group (AG) has long been an important input and asset to the OEC. Two notable additions to the AG were John Unsworth, Dean of Libraries and University Librarian; and Phillip Bourne, Dean, School of Data Science & Professor of Biomedical Engineering. Having senior UVA administrators on the AG helped to solidify the new institutional arrangement with UVA. Arizona State University (ASU) and Illinois Institute of Technology (IIT) remained substantial inputs, with ASU’s Karin Ellison and IIT’s Kelly Laas serving as Co-Principal Investigators. They supported the development of webinars, forums, and other interactive components of the OEC; focused on sustainability by leading the disposition of OEC resources into the UVA open digital repository called LibraOpen; developed bibliographies, teaching materials, and other resources for the OEC; and managed the Ethics Education Library. 

The OEC Editorial Board (EB) worked to identify and review additional materials for the OEC repository, and helped develop and test enhancements to the site to better reach intended audiences and communities. The EB ecompasses eigh areas: Engineering; Life and Environmental Science; computer, Mathematics, and Physical Sciences; Social and Behavioral Sciences; Research Ethics; International Perspectives; Social Justice; and Outreach and Engagement. 

OEC's webinar series: “Working Ethics into the Conversation”, brings together students, academics, and professionals in conversations about ethics. The first webinar, “What Is Professional Responsibility in Engineering?”, was led by OEC AG member Dr. Michael Loui, Professor Emeritus of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, joined by discussant Dr. Jeff Brown, Associate Professor of Civil Engineering at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University. Over 80 persons registered for the webinar, with 65 attending. This webinar laid a solid foundation for subsequent webinars, hosted by Azita Hirsa, Senior Lecturer, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. The webinar series  has become a major factor for OEC impact (along with the Communities of Practice). 

One of the most exciting aspects of this OEC project has been the development and growth of the Communities of Practice (COPs). To stimulate the development of the COPs, the OEC created the OEC Fellows. These OEC Fellows, currently at nine, are assembling groups of OEC members who share specific interests related to research, teaching, and managing STEM related research embedded in an ethics framework. Seven COPs were developed in the following order (along with the lead OEC Fellow(s): (1) Biomedical Engineering Ethics (Dr. Andrew O. Brightman, Purdue University, Weldon School of Biomedical Engineering); (2) Scholars, Educators, and Administrators Fostering Research Integrity (Dr. Julie Simpson, University of New Hampshire); (3) Teaching Ethics to Engineering Students (Dr. Laura Grossenbacher (University of Wisconsin-Madison, College of Engineering) and Dr. Rider Foley (University of Virginia, Department of Engineering and Society); (4) Data Epistemologies and Interpretive Ethics (Dr. Natasha Mauthner (Newcastle University) and Dr. Dena Plemmons (University of California, Riverside); (5) Developing and Implementing Institutional RECR Plans (Katie Bode-Lang, Penn State University); (6) Engineering & Social Justice (Elliot P. Douglas, Ph.D., F. ASEE, University of Florida and J. Britt Holbrook, New Jersey Institute of Technology); and (7) Data Ethics (Dr. Victoria Stodden, University of Southern California, Viterbi School of Engineering). 

The OEC is now functioning as a self-sustaining project of the University of Virginia’s School of Engineering, Department of Engineering and Society, and supported by the work of volunteers from across the United States.
